utterances: Carley, break a leg!
Thank you.
Okay.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION, from NPR News.
Hi gentlemen.
Neil, you know, you mention honesty several times and I'm a writer myself and I enjoy unveiling the nastier side of characters with a fair amount of honesty.

My question to you is, what kind of price have you paid for that honesty, among the people that surround you -- meaning, how many times do people say, gee, he's writing about me, or he's stealing a piece of me to put in there, and it's a piece I'd rather not have shown to the world?
Well, it's funny that you ask that, because I think there's almost, almost no one would be my answer to that.

Because I'm not someone who does pull a great deal from my life, even though I say that, say The Distance from Here, I know those kind of people, having grown up around them, I don't tell, you know, specific stories blanketed in some kind of fiction.
I've changed the names, for instance.

I haven't really written a coming of age story that was really my story, or, I didn't go through, you know, I didn't pull off the In the Company of Men gag, or have somebody, you know, use me as an art project, that kind of thing.
I tend not to pull from the headlines or pull from my own life.
I really do rely a great deal on imagination.
I think what people experience is just that, the sense of, once I've created this story I'm trying to get to the truth of the matter there.
Did you ever work in an office?
We just have a few seconds left.
I did in fact work in an office.
And was David Mammoth (ph) your boss?
You know, one would wish.
I mean, there's a guy who could teach anyone a lesson or two.
The Office just seems such a compelling vision of the American office.

I go back to it often in my writing because I find it's such a life-sucking place where, you know, you have to conform to a certain, you know, set of rules and ideals that often, I think, take away that individual spirit in a person.
And so it, it's really interesting when a person work in that environment how they have to try and switch gears back to being a caring person at home.
I think it's a really difficult mix.
Neil Labure.
First of all, to Don, thank you very much for the call, appreciate it.
You're welcome.
And Neil Labute, thank you so much for joining us today.
We appreciate you for taking the time.
Pleasure.
Thank you.
Neil Labute is a playwright, a filmmaker, and a director.
He's also a prose writer.
His work includes In the Company of Men and The Shape of Things.
The Studio Theater in Washington is showcasing his play, 'Fat Pig', as well as two others of his works.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan, in Washington.
Good morning.
I'm David Greene.
There's this monkey in the Ontario town of Innisfil that escaped from its owner, drove the cops bananas - or drove the cops to use bananas to lure Mango the spider monkey back to captivity.
Mango will now join other monkeys in a local zoo, not the same one that houses another famous Ontario primate, Darwin the Ikea monkey spotted wearing a sheepskin coat at Ikea in 2012.
A spokesperson for the town of Innisfil said we're just happy this monkey business has a happy ending.
It's MORNING EDITION.
Today, delegates and heads of state from almost 200 nations arrive in Paris to negotiate a new agreement to curb global warming.
The first big meeting took place 18 years ago in Japan.
The Kyoto conference produced the first international treaty to slow climate change.
But the treaty fell apart, and scientists say the planet is now closer than ever to a climate catastrophe.
NPR's Christopher Joyce reports that this time negotiators say they've got a radically new approach to avoid a repeat of Kyoto.
You could say the 1990s was when the world got a little scarier.

Scientists said the planet is warming unnaturally and they were pretty sure humans were causing it by burning too much fossil fuels like coal and oil and natural gas that put carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.
Governments met in 1997 in Kyoto, Japan, to do something about it.
Two weeks into the talks, though, it looked hopeless.
People thought their economies would tank without energy from fossil fuels.
Then Vice President Al Gore flew in to reassure everyone that cutting back on CO2 would not break the bank.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
The imperative here is to do what we promise rather than to promise what we cannot do.
A treaty emerged.
It set targets for developed countries to reduce the greenhouse gases that cause warming.
Gore reassured the developing world that they would be exempt.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
We understand that your first priority is to lift your citizens from the poverty so many endure and build strong economies that will assure a better future.
This is your right.
It will not be denied.
I thought we had come a very big step forward.
Harald Dovland represented the Norwegian government in Kyoto.
We had the first commitment.
We had a process on strengthening commitments.
It didn't work out.
Why not?
Well, these emissions cuts were set to start 10 years later so everyone had time to prepare.
But the U.S.
never even signed on.
The Senate would not approve it.
And during that 10 years, China's economy took off.
Their greenhouse gas emissions soared.
Valli Moosa, a South African delegate at Kyoto, says the treaty was handicapped from the start.
You actually cannot have a meaningful agreement without China and the United States being part of it.
It's summertime, and on weekend nights all across the country, that means demolition derby time - cars bashing cars for the pure thrill of it.
Charles Lane from member station WSHU recently went to a demo on New York's Long Island, the legendary home of the demolition derby.
He brought back this audio postcard.
UNIDENTIFIED MAN #1: Fire it up...
A white four-door Chevy Impala.
It's got graffiti writing down the side that says Misery Machine, and it's number 86.
(Singing) Oh baby, give me one more chance.
I also think that gender is playing differently from race in this campaign, and in part that has to do with inflammatory nature of Reverend Wright's remarks.
That was a flashpoint, and we haven't had a similar parallel flashpoint for gender yet, I don't think.

I would argue that we have because the revelation about Governor Spitzer in New York just dominated news for a week, and then the embarrassing, kind of, admissions following up of now - Governor Paterson, raises again this whole issue of fidelity in public life and what it means?
I mean, it is a huge question for families in America, and when you see it played out in the public stage, we all kind of get ""ugh"" about it.
The difference is, the big gender flashpoints for Hillary Clinton in this campaign, over and over again, have had to do with her being a victim.
Think about that tear in New Hampshire.

So I think that the reason this Bill Clinton thing does not hurt or even touch Hillary the way the Reverend Wright touched Obama is because she's always very adroitly played herself as the victim of Bill's philandering.
So she doesn't have to own this the way Obama had to own the Reverend Wright.
Nobody is going to say, account for your husband's infidelity, and what it meant to you because it just looks like it's victimizing her more.

You know, your Slate colleague, John Dickerson, the Political Writer, commenting on email traffic back and forth between you two, just circulating among Slate people, said that actually, the tactical politics of what you are talking about is the least interesting element of this debate.
It is not about the politics.
It is just about how this all makes you feel, about, I guess about ourselves and then, Senator Clinton is a political figure who just is a representative and symbolic figure in this.
What we are on that blog is women who are trying very hard to work through what we see as this very seminal moment in American politics.
We are finally catching up to our, sort of, foremothers of the 1970s to the second wave feminists.
There's this chasm between their experience and ours, and we're trying to work it out.

It seems to me that's exactly what Obama was trying to do, work out this huge generational divide between himself and this very influential figure, the Reverend Wright, trying to say, I understand what you have been through.
Thank you for shattering the barriers that were in your way, so that I could sort of slide through, but here is where you are wrong.
Here is where I need to disavow it.
And it seems that's exactly what the women's movement is grappling with.
I think what is fascinating, really a Rorschach test as what we are going through as a society on these very divisive issues of religion, race, gender that we didn't see coming.
I mean, we didn't know that we were going to be having these conversations, and now we're beset by them.
That's why I sort of would love to hear Hillary Clinton step in and say, OK, I am just going to address head on what's going on between the genders in this campaign.
Here is what it means to me and here is how to fix it.
Dahlia Lithwick and Emily Bazelon, they are contributing writers to the XX Factor blog at Slate.com.
Dahlia, Emily, thank you again.
Thank you.
Our pleasure.
By the way, we have already had an email from you on this subject, maybe we'll have more.
We are going to read letters tomorrow.
Write us, daytoday@npr.org.
And there is more coming, on Day to Day on NPR News.
Meanwhile, Benazir Bhutto's assassination has become a talking point on the campaign trail in Iowa.

Contenders from both parties have reacted to the news by claiming to be the candidate with the most foreign policy experience or the toughest record on national security or even the closest relationship to Bhutto.
We want to make clear that we stand with the people of Pakistan in their quest for democracy.
America feels that strong sense connection, (unintelligible) because of what happened to us.
I have known Benazir Bhutto for a dozen years.
And I knew her as a leader.
I'm the only one with the experience so perhaps it may serve to enhance those credentials or make people understand that I've been to Waziristan.
I know Musharraf.
